column4: it seems like i need to know what kind of file system my partition is, is there a way to check the type of FS?
did you format it yet
whats the /dev/name of the partition?  fdisk -l
fdisk -l returns Cannot open /dev/sda
make a mount point in /media then sudo mount -t vfat /dev/sda4 /media/mountpoint
the mountpoint can be any name
then put that line in /etc/fstab
is that instead of adding it to /etc/fstab?
seems like there is already a /media/disk mountpoint where the partition has been mounted (automatically?)
when you said "put that line in /etc/fstab", do you mean i should put this line:  vfat /dev/sda4 /media/mountpoint
that might be something else, i cant see it
or rather  vfat /dev/sda4 /media/disk
well it should have parameters. i'll give you an example, one sec
/dev/sdb1 /media/LOCAL_DISK vfat rw,nosuid,nodev,shortname=mixed,uid=1000,utf8,umask=077 0 0
replace sdb1 with sda4
oh wow, i would have never come up with that by just looking at the comments within /etc/fstab
that will be easy to access
uid should be your uid
you should read up abit
oh uh, how do i know what my uid is?
its in your /etc/passwd
so that would be the user id?
correct
